title: The 6 Best AI Tools for Content Creation (Step-by-Step Examples for Small Business)
description:
⬇️ Download - 2025 AI and Small Business Adoption Report: http://bit.ly/4gHlyO4  
🎥 WATCH - Google Business Profile: Be Ready When Customers Search: http://thryv.biz/48tbJAY  

Are you spending hours creating content when AI could do it in minutes? In this video, we'll walk you through the 6 best AI tools for content creation—and show you exactly how to use them step by step.  

From one video, we’ll create:  
🎬 5–10 social video clips  
📝 1 blog post  
📲 15 social graphics  
📧 1 email newsletter  

Perfect for small business owners who want to save time, repurpose content, and stay consistent online without burning out.  

Tools Covered in This Video:  
✅ Opus Pro – Extract viral video clips in minutes  
✅ Gemini (Google AI) – Turn transcripts into blogs  
✅ ChatGPT – Generate social media tips + captions  
✅ Canva – Bulk create branded graphics  
✅ Thryv – Generate winning social captions   
✅ Keap – Build engaging AI-powered email newsletters  

Why this matters: 63% of small businesses are already using AI for content creation, and that number is growing fast. If you’re not using AI yet, this is your step-by-step guide to get started.

Watch: Google Business Profile Webinar 🔗 http://thryv.biz/48tbJAY

Guide: The Guide to AI for Small Business 🔗 http://thryv.biz/46jnSXX

Thryv’s marketing and sales platform works behind the scenes to help small businesses get discovered online, convert leads into cash, and create a loyal customer base, effortlessly. We empower small businesses to focus on what matters most: growing their business.

actually in the minority. We surveyed 500 small
business decision makers, and AI usage has
jumped 40% in one year, with 63% already
using it daily for stuff like content creation. So let's dive in and
I will show you how. OK, let's start with video. This is a recording from
a really awesome webinar we did with Google. You can actually watch that
in the description below. But if you're a
small business owner, use a how to video that you
found, or a morning show segment you were featured
on, or even a workshop that you've hosted. To turn this into social
video clips, open up Opus Pro and click Upload File. You can upload from your
desktop or paste a link. I'm going to grab
mine from the desktop. And now that it's
uploaded, you'll see options for how
the clips are made. Don't just click right away. Under Click Model,
for simplicity, we're going to choose Auto. For genre, I'm going to
select Webinar, since that's what I'm working with. And we want clips
that are 30 seconds. Then in the prompt
box, let's type, "Find moments where the
speaker gives actionable tips for improving your
online presence." And let's do a processing
time of about five minutes. Next, you can pick a
stock caption template from the quick presets tab. But I already built a custom
one that uses our brand colors. I think it's fun
that you can also add emojis to make them
super social friendly. And here we go, Opus Pro
just gave us dozens of clips. What I think is super cool
is that you can order them chronologically or
by virality score. This scores the
clip's hook and flow, and helps you predict which
ones will perform best. You can click Preview,
pick the best ones, and then just download an HD. Now, just because we have video
clips doesn't mean that's all we can do. This is one of the
best examples of how to use AI tools for
blogging, especially if you're not a writer. There are a lot of tools
out there that you can use. ChatGPT, Claude, Jasper. But for this example,
let's use Gemini. Instead of scribbling
notes from the webinar, I actually exported the video
transcript from Opus Pro and uploaded it into Gemini. Then let's prompt, "What are the
five main takeaways from this webinar transcript?" And there you have it,
Gemini will quickly give you the top five takeaways. From there, let's prompt again,
"Write a blog focusing on these five takeaways." And just like that, Gemini
has generated a full draft. Now, here is the
really important part. Do not just copy and paste
whatever AI gives you. Always read through
it, make edits, and adjust the tone
so it sounds like you and matches your brand voice. Think of AI as a first
draft, not a final version. Once it looks
good, just hit copy and now you've got a ready
to publish blog post. Now let's promote that blog
with some social posts. First, open up ChatGPT. And again, I'm going to attach
the transcript from Opus Pro and then prompt with
something like, "Give me 15 short social
media friendly tips for this webinar about
improving online presence for small business owners. Make them one-line tips I
can use as Instagram copy." And voila, it'll
generate a list of tips. So go through them
carefully to make sure they're accurate, makes
sense for your audience, and once again, match your tone. If something feels
off or too stiff, you can ask ChatGPT to make
these more casual or more social friendly, and it'll
rewrite them for you. Once you're happy, just copy the
list into Google Sheets or Excel and clean it up by removing any
duplicates, fixing formatting, or adjusting any wording
that you want to fix. And now let's bring
these tips into Canva. Once you open Canva,
choose a template designed for quote posts or tips. Customize the fonts,
background, and colors to match your branding so
everything looks consistent. We want a pretty
grid here, folks. And here is where
the magic happens. Go to Apps and then Bulk Create. Upload your spreadsheet of tips. Select the text area where
you want your tips to appear, and select Connect Data. And then Canva will
instantly create a whole set of posts, one for each tip. Now, it may open these
in a new project. From here, you can
tweak the backgrounds or swap out images
to add variety, but keep the overall
style consistent. Bonus. If you're not sure how to
caption all these amazing posts, ChatGPT can help. Or even better, use AI that's
inside your social posting tool. For instance,
Thryv has CaptionAI that lets you prompt
and instantly generate three captions. You can even toggle options
to include hashtags and emojis or tailor the captions
to specific platforms. Seriously, the best
place to start using AI is within the products
you already use. It's a little less
overwhelming this way. So let's open up Keap
and build a newsletter to showcase the awesome
content we just built. So now that we're in the email
broadcast section of our Keap account, since I send
weekly newsletters, I'm just going to copy
my existing template and update the subject line. Now it's time to update to
promote our new content. For the headline, I will type
3 Tips to Get Found Online." But honestly, we need
to make that punchier. Using Keap's integrated AI, I'll
click the AI suggestion tool and it's going to give me
three tips for enhancing your online presence. That's much better. Now, I want to add a
teaser from our blog post so readers get value
before clicking through. Instead of typing
everything out, I'm just going to paste my
notes and use the AI reformat tool to clean them up for me. Here's where it gets cool. Instead of boring
Read More buttons, Keap AI generates creative CTAs. I'll click Generate New
Buttons and get options, like Unlock Extra Tips. It's way more engaging
and more likely to get people to click through. You can even adjust the tone. Friendly, luxury, bold, witty,
depending on your brand voice. Now, I'm just going to
stick with friendly. And in the in case
you missed it section, I'll link to one of those
social videos we just made. After adding the content, I'll
run the grammar and spelling check to catch any mistakes,
which I am often guilty of. I'm going to make a few more
adjustments to the email, and then we're good to go. I didn't spend a
ton of time laboring over the right words and CTAs
that actually drive action. The smart text feature
saved me so much time, and now all that
content I worked on is available and going to be
sent right to my audience. And that's it. One idea, six tools, and
weeks of content in no time. I'm going to let you
in on a little secret. AI is not just for
content creation. No, small business
owners are already using it for things like
data analysis and customer engagement. In fact, most agree that AI
is no longer a nice to have. It is essential for
reaching new customers and thriving in today's
fast moving economy. And you'd be surprised
how much time and money they're actually saving
using it every single month. All of this is in
our report down in the description below, so
make sure that you check it out. And if you found this
tutorial helpful, let us know by clicking
Like, Subscribe, and clicking that little bell
so you never miss a video. Oh, and if you
want me to show you how to use AI for customer
service or data analysis, drop a comment below and I'll
start working on another video. I'll see you next time. [MUSIC PLAYING]

title: The Latest AI-Powered Content Creation Workflow for Business (Speed Challenge!)
description:
Watch me turn 1 idea into 46 posts across all platforms in just 60 minutes using AI - here's the exact workflow that saves 20+ hours per week.
*Ready to 10x your content with AI? Get our FREE Content Creation Checklist with proven workflows!* 🔗 https://clickhubspot.com/c51be9

Watch me turn one simple 15-minute video into 20 high-quality content assets across 46 posts using nothing but AI tools and a laptop - all in real-time under a 1-hour deadline!

What You'll Learn:
Complete AI content creation workflow from idea to revenue
How to use Descript for video recording, editing, and transcription
Turn 1 long-form video into 8 different content formats
Create short-form clips for TikTok, Instagram Reels, and YouTube Shorts
Generate blog posts, newsletters, and LinkedIn content with AI
Build lead magnets and sales funnels from existing content
Schedule 46 posts across all major platforms efficiently

Timestamps:

01:29 The Challenge Setup & Tools Overview
02:12 Brainstorming with AI (Descript Outline Tool)
03:46 Recording Your Foundation Video
05:19 AI Video Editing (Studio Sound, Eye Contact, Filler Removal)
06:56 Creating YouTube Description & Podcast Show Notes
07:42 Medium Clips for YouTube & LinkedIn (3-5 minutes)

17:08 Social Media Scheduling Strategy
17:49 5 Results: 20 Assets, 46 Posts, 1 Hour

AI Tools & Platforms Used:
Descript (Video recording, editing, transcription, clip creation)
ChatGPT (Content repurposing, email creation, course outlines)
Canva Magic (Visual content, carousels, quote graphics)

Content Formats Created:
Long-form Video (YouTube, podcast)
Medium Clips (3-5 minutes for LinkedIn/YouTube)
Short-form Clips (60-second verticals for TikTok, Reels, Shorts)
Instagram Carousels (Educational slide posts)
Quote Graphics (Social media inspiration posts)
Blog Post (SEO-optimized website content)
Email Newsletter (Audience nurturing)
LinkedIn Newsletter (Professional thought leadership)
X Thread (Twitter engagement)
Lead Magnet (Email list building)
eBook (Low-ticket product)
Course Outline (High-ticket offering)

Key AI Workflow Tips:
Start with one 15-20 minute foundation video for maximum repurposing
Use transcription-based editing to speed up video production
Apply AI tools for studio sound quality and eye contact correction
Repurpose transcriptions across multiple written content formats
Create revenue funnels: Free lead magnet → Low-ticket eBook → High-ticket course
Schedule content in batches using AI-powered social media tools

Perfect for: Content creators, small business owners, digital marketers, entrepreneurs, coaches, and anyone struggling with consistent content creation. 

Experience Level: Beginner to advanced - covers both basic AI tools and sophisticated content workflows.

You can host all your videos on your Google Drive for free and then add it add it to notion as a backup. So, uh let me quickly walk you through uh what my notion looks like so you have a visual idea of like what is possible when you start using notion for content creation. So, uh this is my content hub for notion. I've done many tutorials on how I use notion as a creator and if you want to like go uh deep into it, I will link it in the description below for you to check it out. But uh basically notion allows me to see like all my content across multiple platforms in one centralized location. So uh notion allows you to create something called databases and this is like the master database that I have created for all my different platforms and this is a different view. So this is a content calendar that I created just for Tik Tok and then you can see I have one created for Instagram. I have one for YouTube and all the different platforms that I'm creating content on. So right now if you're just getting started this might seem overwhelming for you because you're just like trying to get started with posting content on one platform and inner you're showing me like 100 different platforms. No, you don't have to be on all these platforms. I just wanted to show you the possibility with notion as you use it more as you evolve as a content creator and you know post on multiple different platforms. So, just to kind of make things easier for you, I've created a free notion content calendar. Uh, so that you know, if you're just getting started, you have your content ideas with all the methods that I teach you on my channel. Next stage is for you to organize all these ideas, you can just get my free content calendar, build on notion, and just add all those ideas on there and then move on to the next stage. And then uh the other thing is notion can also be a very helpful tool in keeping track of what you need to post and when. So let me show you what I mean. So I've created notion uh dashboards for every single platform that I'm on. So let's say that you're going to start creating content on Tik Tok first or YouTube for an example. So, what I highly recommend you do is go to notion, create a free account, and then create a page just for Tik Tok and then add all your content ideas that need to go for the week or the month. So, this is my Tik Tok page inside of Notion. You can create whatever you like for your business or whatever platform that you're creating content on. And the best part about Notion is that you can customize it to however you like. So this is what my page for Tik Tok looks like. So this has everything I possibly need to create content on Tik Tok in one centralized location. And that is what I love about Notion. I can quickly access my Tik Tok profile over here. I can get access to analytics in a click of a button. So I don't have to waste my time going to Google or typing anything in. It's all housed inside of my notion dashboard. And you can customize this to, you know, whatever you like. I just like my things to look a lot more visual because I'm a very visual person. Uh and then I have all the list of ideas for the week. And then these are all the videos that I posted. So, um if you want to see uh a little bit more detail about what my workflow looks like and a full tour of my notion system, uh I'll put that video in the description below for you to check out. So now that you have the perfect free tool to plan and organize your content, the next stage in the content creation process is the actual creation of the content. So I look at content creation in two different aspects. I look at content creation for video and then content creation for graphics. So, for recording your content, I know a lot of people get stuck on what perfect camera should I use, what perfect gear do I need, and you chase all the tech stuff and you don't even record and post a video because you're just so overwhelmed with all the different information that's out there. So, I want you to move as fast as you can and post your first 50 videos on social media. So, what I highly recommend you do is just use your smartphone. And right now, we're living in the best time possible to get started in content creation because we have access to things that people 50 years ago didn't even have access to. And I'm talking about your smartphone. So, when it comes to content creation, you don't need a expensive fancy camera. If you have a smartphone with a decent camera in it, that is more than enough. I actually still record most of my content for my short form content using my uh old iPhone and I have like the old iPhone 13. I don't even have the latest one and I still use this to record all my video content for Tik Tok, YouTube shorts, Instagram res, you name it. So use what you have and don't stress about things that you don't have and be resourceful. So, when it comes to uh putting video out there, one of the biggest mistakes I made is my videos were super dark because I didn't have proper lighting. So, this video is about completely free tools to get started in content creation. So, I'm not going to tell you to go on Amazon and buy a ring light. Uh but those are available and it's very affordable, too. But if you don't even have the budget for a ring light, what I highly recommend you do is stand in front of a window and use natural light. Sometimes natural light can be a lot better than even a ring light. So use what you already have and don't make excuses to get started. So, now that you have natural light and a camera using your phone to record your content, uh let's look at the two best softwares that are out there that is completely free to use when it comes to video editing and then graphic design. So, for video editing, what I personally love and use is Cap Cut. And Cap Cut does have a completely free version for you to get started. And I have many many tutorials on my YouTube channel that shows you how to use Cap Cut. So if you missed that, please check the content creation tips playlist on this channel. And then um if you want an alternative for Cap Cut that is equally good. What I highly recommend is InShot. So for me, I use both Cap Cut and InShot in my tutorials. So they do have free versions that you can get started today. And then the next uh area of content creation is actual graphics. So this includes uh any type of post that is not a video. So there's no movement on it. So this can be a single graphic post or a carousel post. And the best tool that I highly recommend you use that is completely free for beginners is Canva. And I'm pretty sure you know you know what Canva is by now if you have watched any of my other tutorials on my channel. I created over 500 free Canva tutorials for you. So if you're just getting started on Canva and you have no idea how to use it, I want you to watch my tutorials, binge it so that you can start learning Canva today. So one of the biggest questions I get in most of my Canva tutorials is, are you using the pro version of Canva? Can this be done on the free version? Well, there are a lot of benefits in getting the pro version of Canva, trust me, I have been using Canva Pro for years now, but if you only have access or you only have the budget for the free version of Canva, there are a few workarounds and I made a video about what to do if you're on the free version. I'll link it in the description below for you to watch that. But Canva is an excellent tool for you to not just create like social media graphics for your business, but create other content. uh promotional content for your website, landing pages. You can even create like really nice graphics for your digital products, create your digital products all inside of Canva. So, you can like not just create content for social media, but also create digital products to monetize social media. So, um that is all possible inside of Canva. So now that we have the tools to find content ideas, organize content ideas, and create your content, let's go to the next stage of your content creation process, and that is scheduling your content. So the difference between content creators who start posting and then give up after a few posts versus content creators that are established, have been doing this for a long time, is consistency. And I know sometimes this word might sound a little cringe because everyone talks about consistency, but then how do you become consistent? Like no one talks about how you stay consistent. So I've been posting content for years and I post pretty consistently and that is possible by using the right tools. And since this video is about free tools for you to get started, I'm gonna show you the exact tool that I use. Even the free version I used for the longest time. And then now I'm on the pro version, but it is Metrole. And this is a social media scheduling tool that allows you to schedule your content across multiple different social media platforms in one centralized location. So if you go to metricle.com/pricing, you can see the different pricing tiers that they have. So, I am located in the United States. So, I'm going to click on USD. And you can see that they do have a completely free version. So, $0 a month for life. And in their free version, they have up to 50 posts a month at the time of recording this video. So, depending on where you're at, what your budget is, Metro is an excellent tool to start. Uh, and then I do have a completely like broken down tutorial on how to use Metricool. I'll link it in the description below so that you can uh see how to use it. But let me just show you how I use Metriccool. So, um, this is just my content calendar for the week. Uh, and I use Metrocool to plan my content across multiple platforms. And you can see that, you know, all of this is possible because I'm using this tool. So all I then have to do is create uh content for my primary platform which is Tik Tok and then I use that video and then I use Metrocool to schedule it out to all these other social media platforms. So by doing this I am not on my phone all day posting. I'm not you know trying to do all of this manually. I just use the power of automation and these tools to make it possible. And metrical is free for you to get started. All right. Now that we know the best content creation tools that are out there for beginners. So the next question you might have is okay in you told me the best tools. I'm excited to get started but there are so many different social media platforms out there. What platform should I post my content in? Like what should I what should I get started with? So to answer that question I want you to ask yourself these three things. So you need to first identify like who you're speaking to. You need to identify your target audience and then see what platform they're congregating the most. Like what is the platform that they hang out the most? Is it YouTube? Is it Tik Tok? Is it Meta? Like you need to have an idea of that. So once you have an idea of what that platform is, then I want you to focus on just one platform. When you're first getting started and you're brand new to content creation, it's going to be very difficult for you to chase two rabbits at the same time. So, get better at creating content for one platform and then once you hit 100 posts, then you can decide if you want to diversify to the next one. So, for me personally, I started off with Tik Tok. I got comfortable talking to the camera. I got comfortable, you know, creating videos, editing videos, creating graphics. And as I got better every single day with every single post, I decided that I had the bandwidth and the capability to diversify to other platforms. So then I started with YouTube, I started with Meta, Pinterest, all those other platforms. But it started because I took that leap of faith to go and chase one platform. And next, I want you to look at social media platforms in terms of content monetization. meaning what platforms pay creators to post content. So right now there are three of my favorite platforms that pay creators really well for posting content. So number one on that list and my personal favorite is YouTube. So YouTube has been uh paying creators to create content for the longest time now. So if you want to monetize not just your short form content but also your long- form videos uh you know YouTube has a very good content monetization program. And the next best social media platform to monetize your content is obviously Tik Tok. Tik Tok has been launching a lot of content monetization opportunities for creators. And when I say creators, I'm talking about creators in the United States. I know there are some limitations for creators outside the US, but if you are a US-based content creator, Tik Tok has a lot of amazing opportunities. So, just to name a few of the programs that they have, they have something called Tik Tok shop for creators. So, this is basically where you talk about a product that you purchased on Tik Tok shop uh on your video and you link that product in the video itself. So, if somebody purchases through your link, you get um an affiliate commission that's paid inside of Tik Tok. I know YouTube has something very similar to that right now. So, that's called Tik Tok shop on the Tik Tok app. And then they also have something called uh Tik Tok creator rewards program. And this is a program that I'm personally on. And this is where you get rewarded for content that you post on Tik Tok that is within Tik Tok guidelines. Um, and if you uh get,000 views for any video that's over a minute long. So, you get paid depending on what your RPM is, but basically you get paid to create content on Tik Tok. And then two other programs inside of Tik Tok include uh subscriptions. So if you have a certain number of followers on Tik Tok, you can uh turn on subscriptions uh where people can pay you a monthly subscription and you create premium exclusive content just for them. And then also something called creator marketplace and this is where you connect with other brands to either create content for them as branded content or UGC content. So, if you want like a video where I dive deep into what all of these mean, let me know in the comments below and I'll make a dedicated video. But, uh, Tik Tok has incredible opportunities to monetize your content if you are a creator on the platform. And then the third, uh, social media, uh, platform that you should get on in terms of content monetization is Meta. And when I say Meta, I'm talking about both Instagram and Facebook. They do have reals bonuses and then recently just a few months ago they uh launched something called uh content monetization beta on Facebook. So this is very similar to uh the create creator rewards program on Tik Tok and also YouTube partner program on YouTube. Uh it is where you create content and then you get rewarded for creating it on the platform. So, in order for you to qualify, uh, you have to get an invitation. Right now, it's invitation only. And I believe it's also limited by countries. And you can get invited if you are living in the United States. So, if you want to see if you qualify, all you have to do is go to Facebook content monetization data on Google and then you'll get something like this and then you can go ahead and sign up for it and then they will audit your account and see if you qualify and then they'll send you an invitation. So once you get accepted into the program, you want to make sure that you have either a professional account or a business uh Facebook page and then once you start creating content, you can get rewarded for it. So the last and final question you need to ask yourself when it comes to deciding what social media platform should you post your content first is the shelf life of the content or the lifespan of your posted content. So platforms like Pinterest or YouTube is more search engine driven meaning uh the content that you posted a year ago, two years ago might still drive traffic to your offers versus content like Tik Tok or Instagram reels and gets you a lot of traction at first but does die down after a couple of months. So think about that too. And this will depend on what your goals are. Are you creating content to drive traffic to your business? Are you creating cont content to be uh monetizing content on the creator platform? Whatever that may be for you, it's going to be according to your unique situation. So, as I mentioned earlier, think about is my target audience on this platform? Should I create content because of that? Does a platform have good content monetization opportunities so that I can get paid to create content on the platform? And then number three, what does the shelf life or the lifespan of my content looks like? Does that mean I have to create a lot more content, or am I looking at my content creation strategy as more of a long-term commitment than a short-term gain? And that's it. Those are my favorite free content creation tools for you to get started as a beginner on a limited budget. If you have any other questions, let me know what those are in the comments below. And if you haven't subscribed already, make sure to do so. and also hit that notification bell because I'll be creating way more content creation and business tips just like this one. Thank you so much for watching and I'll see you in the next video. [Music]

title: The AI Video Workflow BLOWING UP Businesses in 2026
description:
🎬 Register for the FREE On-demand video masterclass training, "How to Attract Unlimited Clients From YouTube" Just go to: https://wesmcdowell.com/utm/youtube01

Want to create high-quality YouTube videos in just a few hours instead of a few days? In this video, I walk you through five powerful AI workflows that speed up your entire content creation process — from idea to final upload.
These are the same systems I use to stay consistent without burning out and they’ll help you make better videos faster, even if you’re short on time or resources.
If you want to grow on YouTube and attract real clients, this is the video to watch.

🎬 Perfect YouTube Script Formula video: https://youtu.be/h8HlzJFJ-3k?si=0QN9Ca9pJRJ4xxGO

👉Prompt 1:
"I want you to help me come up with YouTube topics and titles that are perfectly aligned with what I charge money for — but also based on what people are actually searching for on YouTube.

Here’s what I need you to balance for me:

The topics must directly connect to my services or the problems I solve for clients.

The keyword phrases need to come from real YouTube searches with enough volume to be worth targeting.

The finished titles should use those same keyword phrases but add a bit of curiosity or emotional pull that makes people want to click.

Before you start, here’s what you need to know about me:

My business: [describe what you sell]

My ideal clients: [describe who they are]

What I help them with: [list the main services or problems you solve]

Now, go to YouTube and find the best keyword phrases related to this business and audience. Make sure they have real search intent and aren’t too broad.

Give me the results in two columns:

Column A: The actual keyword phrase people search for

Column B: A strong, clickable YouTube title that includes that phrase and adds some intrigue

Only include ideas that could realistically help a new channel build authority in this niche. You can give me as many ideas as I ask for (for example, 10 or 52 if I want a year’s worth).

Everything should be based on real research, not guesses."

👉Prompt 2:
“I’m planning a full video about [FILL IN THE BLANK] I already know I want to include the following: [BRAIN DUMP EVERYTHING HERE]

Please do enough deep research to fill in any gaps in my research and inclusions. More specifically, I’d like to see [A FEW MORE TIPS/HELP ME MAKE THIS ARGUMENT/HELP ME ESTABLISH THIS OPINION/REAL WORLD CASE STUDIES/STATISTICS] 

DO NOT take any irrelevant side-quests or tangents along the way. Keep it tight and focused.”

👉CustomGPT Instructions:
"You are my YouTube script-writing assistant.
Use my script formula and writing sample to create new scripts based on the concept, notes, and research I provide.
Follow my formula’s structure and tone exactly, arranging ideas in the most logical order for the viewer.
Eliminate repeated points, simplify complex ideas, and make every line easy to follow and conversational—like natural spoken dialogue.
Each time I start a new script, I’ll give you my concept, notes, and research to begin writing."

🤑 Need Website Hosting? Use my affiliate link to get the best current deal: https://wesmcdowell.com/hostinger

title: I Watched Dan Koe Break Down His AI Workflow OMG
description:
Get the exact blueprint to Build A Content Engine Like Dan Koe (Prompts Included): https://startup-ideas-pod.link/content-engine

Join me as I chat with Dan Koe where he shares his content creation system that allows him to efficiently produce high-quality content across multiple platforms. He explains how he uses Twitter as a testing ground for ideas, then repurposes successful content for newsletters, YouTube videos, and other social platforms. Dan demonstrates how he uses AI tools to research topics, generate content ideas, and analyze successful content structures without sacrificing his unique voice and perspective.

Timestamps:
00:00 - Intro
02:09 - Overview of AI Content Engine
04:45 - How Dan generates newsletter ideas
10:32 - Using Twitter as a litmus test for content ideas
14:19 - Tools Dan uses to find viral content
16:32 - Dan’s AI Workflow and Prompts
21:01 - Daily content creation routine
26:06 - Discussion about visual assets in content
32:20 - Creating Viral Content with AI (Prompt Breakdown)

*Dan uses SuperX. Link: https://superx.so/?via=community

Key Points:
• Dan uses a systematic approach to content creation, starting with Twitter posts to validate ideas before expanding to other platforms
• He leverages AI tools (primarily Claude and ChatGPT) to research, summarize, and generate content ideas
• His weekly workflow includes writing newsletters that become YouTube videos, and creating 2-3 social media posts daily
• Dan uses specific AI prompts to analyze high-performing content and create frameworks for replicating successful formats

1) The Content Ecosystem Framework

Dan's entire content machine runs on just TWO core activities:
• ONE weekly newsletter (sometimes twice)
• 2-3 social media posts DAILY

He writes for Twitter FIRST (280 char limit) then repurposes EVERYWHERE:
• Threads
• Instagram
• LinkedIn
• YouTube scripts
• Reels/TikTok

2) The Newsletter Research Hack

Dan doesn't spend hours taking notes from research. Instead:

• Finds YouTube videos on his topic
• Uses Gemini 2.5 to summarize HOURS of content into digestible notes
• Has AI compare with his previous content to find connections
• Creates an outline from these insights

This turns 6+ hours of research into 1000 focused words!

3) The Idea Validation System

How does Dan know what to write about? Two brilliant approaches:

1. Use Twitter as a testing ground - when a tweet performs well, expand it into a newsletter
2. Study what ALREADY works - find top-performing YouTube videos in your niche, take the TOPIC (not the content), add your unique perspective

4) The AI Content Multiplier

After writing his newsletter, Dan runs it through THREE custom prompts:

• YouTube title generator (creates 20-30 titles based on his best performers)
• Deep post generator (extracts paradoxes, quotes, transformation arcs)
• Content ideas generator (60 ideas based on his top-performing formats)

5) The Daily Content Routine

Dan's productivity system is SHOCKINGLY simple:

• 2 hours of focused writing each morning
• Must complete one newsletter section
• Must write three social posts
• Schedule everything across platforms

That's it. Two hours daily = millions of followers across platforms.

6) The Follower Growth Formula
1. Experiment until you find a post type that generates followers
2. Create consistent "spin-offs" of that format (30% of content)
3. Use remaining 70% to experiment for the NEXT winning format
4. Cycle out older formats as new ones emerge

7) The AI Post Deconstruction Technique
1. Find posts you admire
2. Ask AI: "Break down the structure of this post so I can recreate it"
3. Do this for 3 different posts
4. Have AI combine them into a "complete guide"
5. Ask what context it needs from YOU
6. Create a custom prompt that interviews you then writes in that style

8) The Prompt Engineering Secret

Dan uses a "prompt that helps create better prompts" approach:
- First, get AI to break down what makes great content work
- Then, create a two-phase prompt:
    - Phase 1: Interview you for context
    - Phase 2: Generate content based on your answer


The #1 tool to find startup ideas/trends - https://www.ideabrowser.com

LCA helps Fortune 500s and fast-growing startups build their future - from Warner Music to Fortnite to Dropbox.  https://latecheckout.agency/

Become a member -
https://startup-ideas-pod.link/startup-empire

title: How to use Nano Banana for AI Advertising (FREE Workflow)
description:
Want to create a professional, live-action advert for your business without spending thousands? In this video, I’ll show you exactly how to use AI tools to produce a premium commercial from start to finish — at just a fraction of the cost.

This video features… 

✅ Building a strong foundation with branding strategy
✅ Using ChatGPT for scripting, storytelling & ad copywriting
✅ Designing high-quality visuals with MidJourney & Gemini 2.5 Flash (Nano Banana)
✅ Animating AI video with Kling & Google Veo 3
✅ Insider tips & tricks for advertising, branding, and AI filmmaking

By the end, you’ll know how to plan, generate, and edit a complete AI commercial that feels just as premium as a traditional ad campaign — but at a fraction of the price. Perfect for entrepreneurs, small businesses, marketers, and creators looking to stand out with cinematic content.

Click this link to join the LMArena Discord channel 👇
https://discord.gg/NtYvnEmf55

Click below to try out Flexclip (featuring Kling and Hailuo) 👇

https://www.flexclip.com/editor/ai-tools

Whether you’re building your brand, launching a new product, or just curious about the future of AI filmmaking, this tutorial gives you everything you need to get started.

Timestamps… 

00:00 Intro 
01:30 Building a brand 
04:32 Designing our logo 
05:59 MidJourney image generation

Maybe it's curiosity, maybe it's something deeper, but I have to go and look at this light. And I reach out to touch it. And when I make contact with it, I'm basically transported to a jungle planet. And of course, I just wanted to have a little bit of fun and tie it in with the nano banana theme. So, I fall out of this portal onto this massive mountain of bananas. And then the film ends with me inspecting this glass orb. And I'm just thinking, what on earth have I just discovered? All of that just came from that single starting image that we made on MidJourney. I didn't use chat GPT or anything like that. I just enjoyed writing the story. It's about having fun, right? But now that we have the script and we've started thinking about the individual frames, we can take our starting image into Nano Banana. And we're not going to go through recreating every single frame with you guys, but I can show you just one example so you can understand the process. If we do every single frame, it's going to take absolutely ages. But head on over to lmarena.ai. At the top here, you want to click direct chat. Down here, click generate images. And it's going to automatically go onto Gemini 2.5 image preview brackets nano banana, which I prefer that name. So, we're going to upload our starting image. go back to our script and let's just grab this first prompt here. In fact, it's not really a prompt. Like I said earlier, it's kind of written more like a movie script, but I'm just going to throw this at Nano Banana and just see what type of results we get back. You guys are probably aware that you can access Nano Banana on all sorts of AI sites now, like free pick for example. You can even use it on the Gemini app for completely free. However, it does come with a small diamond watermark in the right hand corner. Cheeky little workaround though. You can use the Gemini app to generate an image that you want and you can then pull it into LM Arena. Ask LM Arena using Nano Banana to remove the watermark from the bottom right hand corner which I actually did for this film. And the quite powerful thing about using Gemini instead of LM Arena is that you can combine multiple images together. And that's actually how I got the final frame of the movie. I basically took the penultimate shot, which is this one here. And I combined it with our starting shot and asked it to generate another close-up of me inspecting the orb, but in that jungle environment, and it worked really well. Like I say, pulled it into Ella Marina, got it to remove the watermark, and then we animated it on from there. Anyway, at the risk of me going off on a tangent like I always seem to do, we have got our generation back from Gemini, and it's amazing. It's actually brought the image to life in a completely different way to what you would have seen in the short film at the start of this video. So, really, you can even use Nano Banana to inspire your plot if you're running out of ideas or if you're at kind of writer's block level. just to have a little bit of fun. Let's just retry this and see what we get on a second run. See how different the variation is from our first generation. So, it's kind of similar. It's gone into a very kind of future tech vibe. I love how the kind of glowing constellations have fused with the floor, though. And I love this kind of crystalline structure over here. This massive spaceship. You can imagine you could build all of these elements into your story if you wanted to. And we'll hit retry one more time just for the fun of it. But you can see this is the process that you would use. You would take your starting image. You'd put it into Gemini or LM Marina or Freepick to access Nano Banana. You'd feed in your prompt and bit by bit you would build up essentially a story board. This one here actually I really really like. If there is any elements of the image that you don't like, you can also go back. I know with Gemini, it's very conversational. It kind of behaves a bit like an LLM, like chat GPT. So, you could say to Gemini, for example, can you remove the futuristic buildings from the scene? And it's going to give you a really nice level of control. But just look how it's put the orb next to my body. I'm kind of flat on my back here. It's completely different to what you guys would have seen in the short film. And of course the key thing is the style, the tone and myself as the character. It all feels consistent. It doesn't kind of break that illusion which I think is the problem with AI film making a lot of the time. Nano Banana essentially becomes your storyboarding mechanic where you're making each of the first frame of every shot for your film. So you can use all different types of camera angles. You can describe different elements, different actions that are taking place within the scene, but of course, it just corresponds back to the script that you've already written. So, you're not kind of plucking things out from thin air. It's following this order that you've already decided on. And like any AI tool, there's going to be a bit of trial and error. You're going to get back some pretty rubbish results from Nano Banana as well, but you can also get back something like this. And if you continually repeated the process, you would get back your entire movie except it would just be in still frames. And if we just run through here now, first of all, it's me laying on my back. I've just kind of come to in this strange sci-fi environment. Then I'm rubbing my head. Really nice establishing shot here. I love what Nano Banana did. Nice closeup. We're trying to get a variation of camera angles here. The texture that Nano Banana gets on my skin here and that kind of change of focal depth is insanely good. Like even looking at this now, it's still blowing my mind. Beautiful reflection of those glowing constellations in the lens of my glasses. Then of course we have the origin of this kind of glowing light which becomes that glass orb weird teleportation ancient device. So I'm kind of looking out over my shoulder here. We're introducing that element. Then I'm walking off into the distance because I'm drawn to this glowing sphere. I need to work out what it is. Then just a bit more variation here and also allowing me to walk towards the finishing point and then stop walking to kind of add a little bit more drama and suspense because we can't see what it is that's drawing me there, right? It's it's hidden from the frame and hidden by a glow as well. Then I knew when I typed this prompt out, this was going to be cool. but reaching out to make contact with this glowing sphere. I will admit that I think the scale is a little bit off. I would have liked the sphere to have been a bit bigger, but you know, I can't make these movies forever. I've got other stuff going on as well. So, it was a cool looking shot. I left it and moved on. And I loved the first closeup of my face so much with the constellations. I thought, wouldn't it be cool to somehow have the glow kind of lighting up my face and directly reflected in my glasses? And when this was animated, this shot looked so cool. Again, we can talk a whole bunch about the texture in my mustache and the kind of imperfections all across my nose. Imperfections are really what make things real. You really want to try and build that into your AI generations. We go onto this amazing over- the-shoulder shot of me holding this glowing glass orb and we get a little bit more textural detail, the object itself. Now, and obviously when I'm asking for this image generation from Nano Banana, we are thinking back to the script and we're thinking that it's going to engulf, you know, the glow is going to get so big that we get transported or sucked into it. And then, of course, we appear in this very different jungle environment, except I still look very consistent. My outfit still looks really consistent. I'm still holding the same glass orb and I'm just looking completely stunned like what on earth has happened. And just to finish up, we have me holding up this orb and thinking I've discovered something incredible here. So now that you have the frames for each beat of the story, it is of course time to animate. And I actually ended up using a fair few different video generators to get the end result you see at the start of the video. Lots of trial and error was involved. So guys, please don't expect it to just work out the box straight away. We're not at that point of AI video generation just yet. Of course, some tools are better than others, but I ended up using Cling, V3, and actually a whole load of Halo. I would say like 90% of the film was generated using Halo. The guys over there were very kind. They gave me a bunch of credits to test out their tools. So, if anyone's watching from Halo, thank you very much. You can kind of see me putting in various different prompts to animate all of our frames. Some of the results I got were amazing. Some of them uh were quite weird. This one, for example, where I'm walking and I just randomly turn around and I look completely different, kind of like a video game character. This one here, even though the result is cool, it isn't actually what I asked Halo to do. And obviously when I turn around to face the camera, you can see it's not very consistent uh in terms of how I actually look. My beard is a lot longer and my face structure quite different. And now this shot here, the final shot or the penultimate shot I should say where I kind of get transported on top of this mountain of bananas. My god, was this hard. And if you're sat there thinking, Jack, you said you were going to tell me how I can animate these images for free. I am. Don't worry, we're going to get to that. But I just really like to show you guys every step of the process so you can understand that this wasn't effortless. This was a lot of trial and error. A lot. You can see this generation here. I kind of fall down, which I didn't want to happen. This one here is pretty good. But then by the time we get to my face, of course, I look completely different. I haven't got glasses. And then when I was trying to get myself to fall onto the mountain of bananas, for whatever reason, uh, Halo kept changing my clothes. So, it kept taking away the astronaut outfit. What I kind of found eventually was that the image I was feeding into it was me holding the orb up like this. And so when it was trying to animate my body, because I was covering my clothing with the starting image, the AI video generators, not just Halo, I have to say, like many of them, didn't know what clothes I was wearing. And of course, you can tell it that you're wearing an astronaut suit, but it's not necessarily going to stay consistent to what we saw me wearing in the rest of the film cuz the AI video generator doesn't know. But you can see all kinds of really wacky results that we got. Again, I get changed to someone completely different. It's kind of actioning prompts that I haven't put in. I I didn't want this to happen at all. Again, here kind of a lens flare and I slide off and I've changed a lot again. And then some of them are just really crazy. Like you guys can see the amount of trial and error involved in creating that film was pretty crazy. But you do learn quite a lot along the way. This one here was really cool, unfortunately. So, I like the way that the glow happens and stuff and I kind of get sucked into it, but then it just drops in a different astronaut there that is not me. So, it kind of just breaks the entire plot, right? This one here, cool portal, but again, it's just put someone else in there. So, I think really I was pushing AI video generation to its absolute limit. But I do want to end on a high note in terms of Halo. Just look at these last couple of video generations, which of course came from this starting frame here. So, we'll go for the first generation I had, which I think ended up making it into the final short film. Really cool. Amazing changes of focal depth to really add some kind of dynamics to the shot itself. And this one here, which I don't think I used in the end, is still really, really cool. I love the way that I kind of take the orb down into the center of frame and I'm still looking at it in my face. Everything looks amazing. The way it animates my eyebrows as I kind of furrow my eyebrows. I'm trying to analyze this object. This is so good. So, yes, a lot of trial and error is involved, but if you stick with it, if you're determined and you have this kind of vision, then you're going to get some amazing results. And as I always like to say, the tools for image and video generation when it comes to AI, they're never going to get worse, are they? They are only ever going to get better. So now is the perfect time to be training yourself with these tools. That's exactly what I like to do on this channel, guys. So if you are enjoying today's content, make sure to whack a like on there for me, consider subscribing, and of course, ring that bell notification icon as well. Now, as promised, I said I was going to show you guys how you can animate your images for free. I mention this in every single one of my videos. So, if you're one of my existing subscribers, I can only apologize guys, but I want to spread the word on this tool cuz I think it's very important. The less pay walls when it comes to AI content creation in my view, the better. So, I will continue to talk about LM Marina and their Discord specifically till the end of time. I will put a link for this Discord in the description, but essentially how it works is you go into the LM Marina Discord. Of course, we already used the web-based version of LM Marina to access Nano Banana without the watermark earlier in the video. Here, we're going to jump into video arena one. That's where I hang out. If you guys ever want to see what I'm creating, you might do. Hit slash and go image to video. Then, let's just drag and drop in our establishing shot. And I want to go back to our script. And we will just grab this prompt here. Just drop it into the prompt section. And we hit return. And now we are going to wait for our generation back. See here it says this generation can take up to 10 minutes. What you're expected and encouraged to do guys is you're going to get back two different outputs from random AI video generators. And the community votes on which output they preferred left or right. So it is a lucky dip. You might get some really bad results. You are also going to get a lot of really good results. And you haven't spent a single penny. So, when I said at the start of the video, you can create what I did in terms of the short film without spending anything, you really can. I'd encourage you to use Mid Journey for your starting frame, but you could just as easily use chat GPT, for example. Write your script and then take your starting image into Nano Banana to create all your different story beats. And then you can pull those frames that Nano Banana gives you into LaMarina Discord for it to animate them for you. Now, I think you can only generate a maximum of eight videos per day. So maybe if you don't want to pay for other video generation tools, it might take you a couple of days to get the results that you're after. But you can do this. You can execute your creative vision and you haven't got to spend loads of money. And speaking of, we have actually just got our generations back from LM Marina's Discord channel. So, we'll just head on over and click here to take a little look at what we got. Let's see. Did we get lucky? That one's very nice. Nice little orbit there that it's done. Very cool. Nice parallax there between the different kind of terrain in the shot. Very, very cool. Really nice level of depth there. And let's see what we got the second time around. So, not very dynamic. Cool parallax between this kind of front layer of constellations and the back layer. I don't hate it, but it's not particularly like punchy or engaging. But again, I'll just draw you guys back to this one here. I didn't pay any money for this. The nano banana generation was free. The animation through Ella Marina's Discord was also free. And just to round off the video, guys, do not underestimate the power and effect finishing touches can have on AI content. We can talk about editing, how we cut the shots together. Do we show the entire length of a shot or just a brief snippet of it? Do we want to reverse the shot or speed it up? Maybe we want to carry out some color correction or something like that. Me personally, I like to add a whole load of film grain on top of my AI video generation just to kind of sell that textural element. And nothing really comes to life until you add music and sound effects. There are a whole load of places you can get these for free and royalty-free as well. site that I tend to use a whole load is one called Pixabay. I am on here all the time getting sound effects. And you can also go on to YouTube's music library as well, which I believe is where I actually source that opening piece of music I use in most of my YouTube videos. Here it is here, the YouTube audio library. So, you know that you haven't got to pay any money for these. And again, they are going to be copyright free, too. safe to use on YouTube and therefore safe to use across your socials as well. I say it's kind of 50/50. There is a lot of quite rubbish stuff on here. I'm going to be brutally honest, but if you do enough digging, you're going to find some cool stuff as well. Combining your sound effects and your music is really going to sell that finished product. All the elements have to come together. AI can't just do everything for you. the human element, you as a creator, is still fundamentally important to the process. And that's why AI doesn't really scare me as much as it used to because I know that a final output like the one you see at the start of the film could just not be created with AI. Could an AI have come up with the idea? Could it have tr video generations that weren't doing what I wanted it to? Could it have since checked over the nano banana exports to make sure that they were consistent enough to keep the vision alive? And could it have then searched for relevant music to create the tone that I'm after? And then all these different sound effects as well. I know V3 is quite good at that, but I really still feel we as creators are very important here. AI just gives you the tools to execute your vision in a whole new way. I really do hope you guys have enjoyed today's video. I've absolutely loved playing around with Nano Banana and the growth on this YouTube channel. It means the absolute world to me, guys. I try to read and respond to as many comments as I possibly can, but if you have any questions, and if you have ideas for future videos as well, make sure to drop them down below. Can't always respond to all the comments now, but I really do try my best. As always, if you have enjoyed today's content, make sure to like, hit that subscribe button, and of course, ring the bell notification icon so you don't miss any future videos, cuz I'm putting out as many as I possibly can. Have a great rest of your day, guys, and enjoy this new tool.

title: I Just Found a NEW and FREE AI Video Generator for Long-Form Video
description:
*FREE NEW AI Video Generator: Let’s Create AI Videos with MovieFlow*
MovieFlow AI is a free AI video generator that allows creators, marketers, and educators to make professional long-form videos without paying upfront. Unlike most platforms that limit users to short 5-second clips, MovieFlow can generate cinematic videos up to 3 minutes long for free. With a built-in AI agent and ready-to-use templates, MovieFlow is quickly becoming one of the best options for free unlimited AI video generation, AI filmmaking, and automated content creation.

*What is MovieFlow AI?*
MovieFlow AI is a next-generation AI movie maker designed to make high-quality video production accessible to everyone. The tool combines text-to-video technology, creative templates, and intelligent automation. Users can generate social media clips, music videos, anime sequences, or educational tutorials with just a few prompts. The platform follows a freemium model: all users can create long-form AI videos for free with a watermark, and only pay if they want to remove the watermark for commercial use.

👉 Try MovieFlow AI for FREE today using my invite link: https://movieflow.ai/signup?inviteCode=7G60LEAQ
📺 Also check out  https://www.youtube.com/@MovieFlow_Official on YouTube for more updates. 

*Key Features*
1. Agent Mode
The built-in AI agent works like a virtual production team. Describe your idea in detail, choose video duration, aspect ratio, and language, and the AI generates your video. Users can edit results manually or ask the AI to make adjustments through chat commands.
2. Inspiration Lab
A large library of ready-to-use templates across categories such as Narrative, Commercial, Music Video, Education, 2D Anime, and 3D Anime. Templates are updated regularly to reflect current trends, such as seasonal or event-based content.
3. AI Music Video Generator
Users can create professional music videos by selecting a template, providing parameters like song length, visuals, concept, and storyline, and letting the AI generate the final result.
4. AI Ad Video Generator
The Commercial template gallery allows brands to produce user-friendly promotional videos. Simply enter a script, upload product visuals, and adjust mood and style to generate polished ads.
5. Anime Templates
MovieFlow includes specialized 2D and 3D anime templates, making it an attractive AI anime video generator. With customizable prompts and references, creators can build anime content at scale.

*Why Choose MovieFlow?*
Most AI video generators are limited in duration and require upfront payments. MovieFlow breaks this barrier by offering free long-form video generation, making it one of the most versatile options for:
1. Content creators who want social clips and storytelling content.
2. Marketers testing ad concepts with a free AI video generator.
3. Educators building engaging video lessons.
4. Filmmakers experimenting with AI filmmaking tools.
MovieFlow competes with other platforms such as Sora 2, Veo 3.1, Kling AI, and Hailuo AI, but stands out with its combination of long video duration, ease of use, and ready-to-use templates.

title: Use AI to create automated social media content | Freepik Use Cases
description:
Learn how to use AI to create automated social media content with Freepik Spaces. This template demonstrates how AI workflows help teams generate visuals, videos, and copy all in one place, turning social media creation into a fast and collaborative process. Upload an image, run the nodes, and customize as needed. You can add or remove nodes depending on your goals. Then, share your project and let your team provide feedback directly within Spaces.

💡 Key insights
• Create visuals, videos, and copy in one unified Space.
• Automate your content creation workflow with AI nodes.
• Keep your brand look consistent using prompts and image references.
• Collaborate with your team in real time using editable templates.

✏️ Step-by-step workflow
1. Open AI Suite → Spaces.
2. Go to Templates and select Create Social Media Content.
3. Click Use Template to make your editable copy.
4. Upload your product photo in the Input node.
5. Edit Text nodes to define tone, scene, and brand style.
6. In the Image Generator node, select Nano Banana for visual consistency.
7. Choose your format: 4:5 for Instagram, 9:16 for TikTok, or 16:9 for YouTube.
8. Add a Text node for your brand rules (colors, typography, composition).
9. Connect to another Image Generator node and run it.
10. Add an Upscale node for resolution and sharpness.
11. Animate your visuals with the Video Generator node (Google Veo 3.1).
12. Generate captions and hashtags using Text and Assistant nodes.
13. Save or share your automated workflow with your team.

🔗 Useful links
🌐 Explore Freepik Spaces: http://www.freepik.com/spaces
🔹 Try this template: https://www.freepik.com/pikaso/spaces/a03f6e47-76b9-4eb0-8c95-2539cc5675e9
